Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A field, laboratory and theoretical study of mixed bedrock-alluvial meandering rivers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is the meandering of river channels, an iconic phenomenon in geomorphology and a fundamental process of channel morphodynamics. The goal is to advance our understanding of meander morphodynamics in eroding channels enough to develop a general theoretical framework for channel meanders in a variety of environments. A particular focus is the meandering of mixed bedrock-alluvial channels and the role of sediment cover in the mediation of patterns of channel erosion. Such processes are being studied through a combination of field studies, laboratory experiments, numerical simulations and theoretical analysis. Novel aspects of the research include: (i) the study of micro-scale dissolutional meanders in the field and the laboratory as a proxy for macro-scale abrasional meanders, and (ii) the development of meander morphodynamic model whose channel cross-section is not fixed but rather evolves according to a plug-in constitutive equation for erosion rate.

Meandering streams and rivers are a vital part of the natural landscape of the United States and beyond. Over the centuries, many of these rivers have been modified drastically and their crucial environmental role compromised. Remediation of these rivers has become a priority in recent years as the negative effects of such environmental damage have become clear. For remediation to succeed, and for the assessment and management of meandering rivers to be effective, a thorough understanding of channel morphodynamics is needed. The aim of this project is to deepen such understanding and to pass on these advances to the broad community of scientists and engineers interested in the topic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theme of this research project has been the dynamic morphology of river channels undergoing erosion. The main aim has been to improve our understanding of meandering processes in such rivers, tackling the problem from field, laboratory and theoretical perspectives.

The field focus has been on incising meandering rivers in Shikoku, Japan, and in particular on the Shimanto River, which has long stretches of beautifully exposed bedrock channel beds, and multiple knickpoints and allied benches, in series of tight meander bends whose fast lateral motion is recorded in multiple cutoff loops and straths. Three key observations were made: (1) macro-roughness of the bedrock bed (meter-scale rugosity) is a basic control on the fraction of bedrock exposure as a function of sediment cover; (2) knickpoints of various scales are propagating up the sinuous channel, quickly across weak lithologies and slowly across stronger rock, but not being generated or blocked by lithological boundaries; (3) these knickpoints are where the bulk of the vertical erosion in the channel is concentrated, as the downstream boundary condition (broadly net uplift) is propagated upstream, leaving benches in their wake (often around the outer bend perimeters), and putting a big question mark over typical “channel-average” methods of treating rates of downcutting. These observations led us to redirect our theoretical and laboratory studies to match.

The theoretical foci were twofold: (1) Development of a so-called “macro-roughness” model for erosion by saltation-abrasion and sediment throughput in bedrock channels, where the degree of bed cover is mediated by meter-scale bed topography and by the amount of sediment stored in a transient fashion across it. This model is the first to realistically describe the propagation of knickpoints in bedrock and in alluvium in such rivers, and to handle the long-profile evolution of such rivers in a relatively simple set of equations. Analysis of these equations reveals how knickpoint motion originates in kinematic waves whose speed can be derived analytically once properties of the sediment etc are known. (2) Development of a queueing-theory based model for cover-saltation-abrasion, building on work by Einstein, Ancey and Turowski. Although analytically somewhat complex, this model makes simple predictions for probability distributions of grain impacts on bedrock as a function of sediment flux and cover. Understanding of such distributions is fundamental to understanding the larger scale behavior of eroding river channels.

The laboratory studies focused on reproducing the Shimanto River in an idealized form on the Kinoshita meandering flume in the Ven Te Chow lab at Urbana-Champaign. Preliminary results show that the formation of outer-bend benches arises naturally as a result of the evolution of partial bed cover by sediment. Future work will seek to unify such experimental results more comprehensively with our field and theoretical insights.
